concept.title: Quick Start Step 5:
concept.shortdesc: The following examples describe a typical process of pushing an application to using .

conbody.note: For detailed instructions on using the cf push command and deploying applications, see the Cloud Foundry Documentation.

stentry.b: Getting Ready to Push Your First Application

ol.li: Ensure you are targeting the desired cluster, for example:cf api http://api.203.0.113.0.xip.ioIf you cannot connect to , ensure that your connection has no proxy settings.
Ensure that you are logged into the desired cluster:cf loginYou are prompted for your username and password.To skip SSL validation, you can add the --skip-ssl-validation option.
Create and target an organization:cf create-org <organization> cf target-o <organization>
Create a space, attach it to your organization, and target it:cf create-space <space> -o <organization> cf target -o <organization> -s <space>

stentry.p: Your application is deployed to the cluster.
stentry.b: Pushing an Application to the Sandbox Deployment

ol.li: Navigate to the GitHub page of the application and click Download ZIP.
Decompress the .zip file into a convenient directory.
Navigate to the directory that contains your application and its .yml file, and ensure that the .yml file is configured correctly.
Target the sandbox deployment, for example:cf target http://api.203.0.113.0.xip.io
Ensure you are logged into the cluster:cf loginYou are prompted for your username and password.

Push the application:cf pushAt the end of the process, Cloud Foundry displays the URL of the application, formatted using the xip.io wildcard DNS, for example:urls: myAppName.203.0.113.0.xip.ioYou will need this URL to use the Cloud Foundry CLI. You can also run the cf apps command to see detailed information about your application.
If you experience a problem, run the cf delete <appName> command, make the necessary adjustments, and then push the application again.For detailed instructions, see the Cloud Foundry documentation:
Deploying an Application
Deploying with Application Manifests
Troubleshooting Application Deployment and Health

stentry.p:
The following are sample applications to get you started:
GitHub Stats Widget for Dashing (Ruby)
Show Environment Variables (Node.js)
Show Environment Variables (Go)
